abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and the institutional development
            impact is high. Lessons convey that success was driven
            primarily by highly committed staff, from both the Bank, and
            Albania, who ensured flexibility in project design,
            emphasized the necessary institutional framework, and
            carried out intensive supervision. However, minor
            shortcomings suggest that rapid institutional change, may
            divert attention from other objectives, unless key
            performance indicators have been clearly defined, and are
            being monitored. This means that further attention could
            have been given to potential synergies, such as addressing
            explicit trade-offs, namely, the shift from rural poverty
            reduction, that is, channeling resources to poor rural
            households, into rapid institutional development, that is,
            developing financial institutions in the economically most
            viable villages, and could thus have served better, if
            addressed at project preparation, and during implementation.
            The success of the rural micro-credit program, stems from an
            early village level involvement in the design of the
            participatory delivery mechanism, which was piloted and
            adjusted to local conditions, and where loan decisions were
            made at the village level. It proves that even under extreme
            conditions of institutional weakness, and civil instability,
            such programs can sustain repayment performance, if
            ownership is rooted at the community level.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Rural Development
            Project are to: promote small farm and off-farm activities
            and help restart a rural market economy; to repair basic
            rural infrastructure; and to create employment for the rural
            population and inject cash resources into rural households.
            The project components are: 1) rural works to rehabilitate
            small infrastructure, such as ex-cooperative dirt roads,
            village water supply or irrigation systems, schools and
            health care centers, and market facilities; 2) small-scale
            credit to extend the existing village credit fund network
            and provide small loans to farmers and other rural
            microentrepreneurs for all types of income-generating
            activity; 3) promotion of rural activities by providing
            business and technical advice, and promoting and supporting
            the creation of village animal health associations to
            improve prophylaxis; and 4) studies and local government training.
